content:
Imagine you are a robot browsing the web, just like humans. Now you need to complete a task. In each iteration, you will receive an Observation that includes a screenshot of a webpage and some texts. This screenshot will feature Numerical Labels placed in the TOP LEFT corner of each Web Element.
Carefully analyze the visual information to identify the Numerical Label corresponding to the Web Element that requires interaction, then follow the guidelines and choose one of the following actions:
1. Click a Web Element.
2. Delete existing content in a textbox and then type content. 
3. Scroll up or down. Multiple scrolls are allowed to browse the webpage. Pay attention!! The default scroll is the whole window. If the scroll widget is located in a certain area of the webpage, then you have to specify a Web Element in that area. I would hover the mouse there and then scroll.
4. Wait. Typically used to wait for unfinished webpage processes, with a duration of 5 seconds.
5. Go back, returning to the previous webpage.
6. Google, directly jump to the Google search page. When you can't find information in some websites, try starting over with Google.
7. Answer. This action should only be chosen when all questions in the task have been solved.

Correspondingly, Action should STRICTLY follow the format:
- Click [Numerical_Label]
- Type [Numerical_Label]; [Content]
- Scroll [Numerical_Label or WINDOW]; [up or down]
- Wait
- GoBack
- Google
- ANSWER; [content]

Key Guidelines You MUST follow:
* Action guidelines *
1) To input text, NO need to click textbox first, directly type content. After typing, the system automatically hits `ENTER` key. Sometimes you should click the search button to apply search filters. Try to use simple language when searching.  
2) You must Distinguish between textbox and search button, don't type content into the button! If no textbox is found, you may need to click the search button first before the textbox is displayed. 
3) Execute only one action per iteration. 
4) STRICTLY Avoid repeating the same action if the webpage remains unchanged. You may have selected the wrong web element or numerical label. Continuous use of the Wait is also NOT allowed.
5) When a complex Task involves multiple questions or steps, select "ANSWER" only at the very end, after addressing all of these questions (steps). Flexibly combine your own abilities with the information in the web page. Double check the formatting requirements in the task when ANSWER. 
* Web Browsing Guidelines *
1) Don't interact with useless web elements like Login, Sign-in, donation that appear in Webpages. Pay attention to Key Web Elements like search textbox and menu.
2) Vsit video websites like YouTube is allowed BUT you can't play videos. Clicking to download PDF is allowed and will be analyzed by the Assistant API.
3) Focus on the numerical labels in the TOP LEFT corner of each rectangle (element). Ensure you don't mix them up with other numbers (e.g. Calendar) on the page.
4) Focus on the date in task, you must look for results that match the date. It may be necessary to find the correct year, month and day at calendar.
5) Pay attention to the filter and sort functions on the page, which, combined with scroll, can help you solve conditions like 'highest', 'cheapest', 'lowest', 'earliest', etc. Try your best to find the answer that best fits the task.

Your reply should strictly follow the format:
Thought: {Your brief thoughts (briefly summarize the info that will help ANSWER)}
Action: {One Action format you choose}
Confidence: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating your confidence level in the action. A higher value means greater confidence.}
Completion: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating how much of the task has been completed until now. Zero means no progress has been made and one means full completion.}

Then the User will provide:
Observation: {A labeled screenshot Given by User}

Now given a task: Find an Intermediate-level online course on Coursera about 'Blockchain Technology' which lasts between 1 to 4 weeks, and is provided by a well-known institution. Also, note the course's main goals and the instructor's name.  Please interact with https://www.coursera.org/ and get the answer.Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: To find an intermediate-level online course about 'Blockchain Technology', I need to use the search function. The search button (magnifying glass icon) is clearly labeled. Next, I should enter the appropriate search term.
Action: Click [2]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.1
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The search textbox is now available at the top labeled "What do you want to learn?". I should enter "Blockchain Technology" to find relevant courses.
Action: Type [1]; Blockchain Technology
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.2
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: I need to find an intermediate course on Blockchain Technology that lasts between 1 to 4 weeks from a well-known institution. The third card, "Blockchain Applications in Fintech" by INSEAD, matches the duration (1-4 weeks), but its level is "Beginner," not "Intermediate." The first card, "Blockchain" by University at Buffalo, is intermediate but lasts 3-6 months, which is too long. I need to scroll down to check for more matching results.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; down
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.2
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: None of these courses meet the requirement of being intermediate-level and lasting 1–4 weeks. All displayed are beginner-level and 3–6 months in duration. I need to look for filtering options that can help narrow down by difficulty level or duration.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; up
Confidence: 0.85
Completion: 0.2
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: There are filter options on the left side, but none visibly allow filtering by course level or duration directly. The sort feature at the top right ("Sort by: Best Match") might contain helpful options, or additional filters may be hidden. It's worth checking if the sort/filter dropdown includes those criteria.
Action: Click [22]
Confidence: 0.9
Completion: 0.25
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The sort options shown only include "Best Match" and "Newest" and do not help filter by level or duration. The course "Blockchain Applications in Fintech" by INSEAD (rightmost card) matches the desired duration (1-4 weeks) and comes from a well-known institution, but it is listed as "Beginner" level. I need to check for more filter options that allow filtering by level or duration, likely found by scrolling or clicking any expandable options on the filter bar.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; down
Confidence: 0.9
Completion: 0.3
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The additional courses shown are also beginner-level and last 3-6 months, which do not meet the requirements. The left-side filter bar may have more filtering options if "Show 3 more" under the Subject category is used, or further scrolling could reveal level/duration filters.
Action: Click [12]
Confidence: 0.85
Completion: 0.35
The action you have chosen cannot be exected. Please double-check if you have selected the wrong Numerical Label or Action or Action format. Then provide the revised Thought and Action.

Thought: The "Show 3 more" button [12] is not visible in this screenshot, indicating I made an error referencing a previous observation. To discover additional filtering options not currently visible (like Level and Duration), I should continue scrolling down the window to inspect the full filter menu.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; down
Confidence: 0.85
Completion: 0.35
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: A new course card for “Supply Chain Finance and Blockchain Technology” by New York Institute of... is visible. It is intermediate-level but lasts 3-6 months, missing the 1-4 week requirement. Still, no filters for level or duration are visible yet. I should scroll further to try to reveal the complete filter section for more options.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; down
Confidence: 0.9
Completion: 0.4
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The course "Blockchain Business Models" by Duke University is intermediate level and lasts 1-3 months, which is still longer than the 1-4 week requirement. No 1-4 week, intermediate-level courses are visible. I should continue scrolling down to see if any courses fit the 1-4 week duration requirement and are intermediate level.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; down
Confidence: 0.9
Completion: 0.5
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The course "Blockchain Business Models" by Duke University is still the only intermediate-level course, but its duration is 1-3 months, not 1-4 weeks. No matching intermediate-level, 1-4 week courses are visible. I need to scroll further to search for a suitable course or for additional filters to refine by duration or level.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; down
Confidence: 0.9
Completion: 0.55

content.text:
Observation: please analyze the attached screenshot and give the Thought and Action. I've provided the tag name of each element and the text it contains (if text exists). Note that <textarea> or <input> may be textbox, but not exactly. Please focus more on the screenshot and then refer to the textual information.
[1]: "Best Match";	[2]: "selected";	[3]: "Newest";

content:
Thought: The course "Web3 and Blockchain Fundamentals" by INSEAD has a duration of 1-4 weeks and is provided by a well-known institution, but the level is marked as "Mixed" instead of strictly "Intermediate." No strictly intermediate, 1-4 week courses are visible; the only other intermediate course, "Complete DApp - Solidity and React - Blockchain Development," is too long (3-6 months). I should click on the "Web3 and Blockchain Fundamentals" course for more details to check if intermediate-level learners are a targeted audience and to extract main goals and the instructor's name.
Action: Click [5]
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.7
The action you have chosen cannot be exected. Please double-check if you have selected the wrong Numerical Label or Action or Action format. Then provide the revised Thought and Action.

Thought: The correct action is to click on the course card visually present for "Web3 and Blockchain Fundamentals" by INSEAD to view its details. Since this course is in the top row, middle card, I need to click on that element for more information. There is no visible numerical label directly on the card, so I'll reference the visible course and its position accordingly. The next sensible approach is to scroll to check if there is a strictly intermediate, 1–4 week course, but if none appears, this "Mixed" level course by a renowned institution may be the best fit.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; down
Confidence: 0.85
Completion: 0.7

Thought: The newly visible courses, "Blockchain and Cryptocurrency Explained" and "Blockchain Basics," both last 1–4 weeks but are beginner level. The intermediate course present ("Secure DApps...") is still too long (3-6 months). No intermediate-level, 1–4 week blockchain technology course appears on this page. Since scrolling has revealed multiple cards, it is likely none fit all requirements except the "Web3 and Blockchain Fundamentals" with "Mixed" level from a well-known institution, visible earlier. I'll scroll down once more to confirm if any truly intermediate, 1–4 week options appear.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; down
Confidence: 0.85
Completion: 0.75

content:
Thought: All visible courses with a 1-4 week duration that mention blockchain are labeled "Beginner" or "Mixed," not strictly "Intermediate." The course "The Blockchain" from University of California may be relevant, but we must confirm its level and duration. "Introduction to Blockchain for Financial Services" by INSEAD is labeled as well-known, but the level and duration are not fully displayed in this view. None appear to be strictly intermediate in the 1-4 week range. Therefore, the closest match according to all requirements is a "Mixed" level course. I should select "Web3 and Blockchain Fundamentals" from INSEAD, as previously identified, for more details, since it is from a reputable institution and fits the specified duration.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; up
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.8
